questions.text: Low serum phosphate with normal calcium levels is found in which of the following common causes of hereditary rickets?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

X-linked dominant hypophosphatemic rickets presents with renal phosphate wasting, leading to hypophosphatemia with normal calcium levels.

It is the most common form of hereditary rickets.

  • Inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern due to mutations in the PHEX gene.
  • Causes renal tubular phosphate wasting, leading to low serum phosphate.
  • Calcium levels remain normal, as the abnormality is not due to vitamin D deficiency.
  • Alkaline phosphatase is elevated, and patients present with bone pain, deformities, and short stature.
  • These patients are resistant to vitamin D therapy and require phosphate supplementation and active vitamin D analogues (calcitriol).

Explanation of other options:

Vitamin D-dependent, type I (Option B): Autosomal recessive defect in 1α-hydroxylase enzyme; both calcium and phosphate are low due to defective vitamin D activation.

Vitamin D-dependent, type II (Option C): Due to vitamin D receptor mutation; causes hypocalcemia and hypophosphatemia, with rickets resistant to vitamin D.

X-linked recessive hypophosphatemic rickets (Option D): Incorrect inheritance pattern; X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets is dominant, not recessive.

questions.text: A 3 year old child presented to the OPD with deformities of lower limb. X-ray taken is given above. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above x-ray shows the classical findings of splaying, cupping and fraying of metaphysis, seen in Rickets.

Radiological signs of Rickets:

  • Delayed appearance of epiphyses.
  • Widening of the epiphyseal plates(earliest change)
  • Cupping of the metaphysis
  • Splaying of the metaphysis
  • Fraying of the metaphysis
  • Rarefaction of the diaphyseal cortex occurs late.
  • Bone deformities: Bow legs(bilateral genu varum) is the most common deformity seen in rickets.

Explanation of other options:

Scurvy (Option A): Scurvy shows ground glass bones, white line of Frankel, Pelkan spurs, and subperiosteal hemorrhages-not metaphyseal splaying or cupping typical of rickets.

Osteosclerosis (Option C): Refers to increased bone density, seen in conditions like fluorosis or osteopetrosis, not metaphyseal deformities or rachitic changes.

Osteogenesis imperfecta (Option D): Presents with osteopenia, multiple fractures, and possibly blue sclera, not metaphyseal cupping, fraying, or genu varum seen in rickets.

choices.text: Hereditary Vitamin D dependant rickets type I
Hereditary Vitamin D dependant rickets type II

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with delayed milestones, bowing of legs, and widened wrists. Laboratory investigations shows low serum calcium, low phosphate, elevated alkaline phosphatase, low levels of 1,25(OH)2 vitamin D despite normal 25(OH) vitamin D levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Loss of 1-alpha hydroxylase activity leads to low 1,25(OH)2vitamin D despite normal 25(OH) levels, causing type I vitamin D-dependent rickets.

  • Hereditary Vitamin D-dependent rickets type I (also called pseudovitamin D deficiency rickets) is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the gene encoding the enzyme 25(OH) vitamin D-1α-hydroxylase.
  • This enzyme is essential for the conversion of 25-hydroxyvitamin D [25(OH)D] to 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D [1,25(OH)2D], the active form of vitamin D.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Vitamin D obtained from the diet or sunlight is first converted in the liver to 25(OH)D.
    • The renal 1α-hydroxylase enzyme (defective in this condition) converts it into 1,25(OH)2D.
    • Without this enzyme, even with normal or high 25(OH)D levels, there is inadequate active vitamin D, leading to:
    • Decreased intestinal calcium and phosphate absorption
    • Increased parathyroid hormone (secondary hyperparathyroidism)
    • Increased bone turnover with inadequate mineralization causing rickets
  • Typical Biochemical Profile:
    • Serum calcium ↓ Low
    • Serum phosphate ↓ Low
    • Alkaline phosphatase ↑ High
    • 25(OH) Vitamin D Normal
    • 1,25(OH)2 Vitamin D ↓ Low (key feature)
    • PTH ↑ High
  • Clinical & Radiological Features:
    • Delayed milestones, bowing of legs, rachitic rosary, craniotabes, widened wrists
    • X-rays show metaphyseal cupping, fraying, and splaying
  • Treatment:
    • Responds well to calcitriol (1,25(OH)2D) supplementation
    • Requires monitoring of calcium and phosphate levels

Explanation of other options:

Hyperphosphatemia (Option A): This child has hypophosphatemia, not hyper; phosphate is low due to impaired absorption.

Vitamin D-resistant rickets (Option B): Seen in hypophosphatemic rickets where vitamin D levels are normal but there is renal phosphate wasting.

Hereditary vitamin D-dependent rickets type II (Option D): Caused by vitamin D receptor defect; here, 1,25(OH)2 D is elevated, but the target tissues are unresponsive.

questions.text: The active form of vitamin-D(calcitriol) is produced by the enzyme 1-alpha-hydroxylase. What hormone activates this enzyme?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Parathyroid hormone (PTH) stimulates 1-alpha-hydroxylase in the kidney, promoting conversion of 25(OH)D to active 1,25(OH)2D (calcitriol).

  • The precursor to calcitriol is stored in the skin where UV exposure converts it to previtamin D3. Then, it is bound to vitamin-D binding protein(DBP) where it is carried to the liver and metabolized to 25-hydroxyvitamin D.
  • When calcium is low, parathyroid hormone(PTH) levels become elevated which activates 1-alpha-hydroxylase which converts it to the active Vitamin D(calcitriol).
  • Its most potent effect is to enhance intestinal calcium absorption through DNA regulation. Illustration shows a diagram of Vitamin D metabolism.

Explanation of other options:

Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) (Option A): TSH regulates thyroid hormone production, not vitamin D metabolism.

Estrogen (Option C): Estrogen influences bone metabolism, but does not directly regulate 1-alpha-hydroxylase activity.

Calcitonin (Option D): Calcitonin inhibits osteoclast activity, but has no significant role in activating 1-alpha-hydroxylase.

questions.text: A 7 month old child is brought to the OPD with signs, symptoms and biochemical changes of rickets. Which of the following findings is unlikely to be found in this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Long bones of legs get deformed only after the child starts weight bearing, so a 7 month old child will never develop deformities of the lower limb. Hence bow legs are unlikely to be found.

Clinical features of rickets:

  • Craniotabes(earliest sign)
  • Frontal bossing
  • Rachitic rosary
  • Harrison's groove
  • Pectus carinatum(pigeon chest)
  • Broadening of the ends of long bones, most prominently around wrists and knees. It is seen around 6-9 months of age.
  • Delayed teeth eruption is noticed in infants.
  • Muscular hypotonic: The child's abdomen becomes protuberant(pot belly) because of marked muscular hypotonia. Visceroptosis and lumbar lordosis can occur.
  • Deformities: Deformities of the long bones develop, once the child starts walking. The most common deformity is bilateral genu varum, also called bow legs.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a treatment option for osteoporosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Corticosteroids are a known cause of osteoporosis, not a treatment option. In fact, long-term use increases fracture risk.

  • Corticosteroids causes osteoporosis
  • The drug of choice for osteoporosis is Bisphosphonates.
  • Vertebroplasty is a minimally invasive surgical procedure used to treat compression fractures of vertebrae that are seen in osteoporosis.
  • The drugs that can be used of osteoporosis are given below

Classification of Osteoporosis:

  • Primary:
    • Type 1(postmenopausal)
    • Type 2(senile or involutional)
    • Type 3("post climacteric", it is not a part of original classification, but is similar to type 1 osteoporosis but occurring in males)
  • Secondary:
    • Hormonal: Hypogonadism, thyrotoxicosis, Cushing's, hyperprolactinemia and diabetes mellitus
    • Drugs: Steroids, phenobarbital, anticonvulsants, anticoagulants, cytotoxic agents, etc.
    • Nutritional: Calcium deficiency, vitamin C and vitamin D deficiency, malabsorption, alcohol intake and malnutrition
    • Metabolic diseases: Osteogenesis imperfecta, homocystinuria, Marfan's syndrome, etc.
    • Chronic liver and renal disease
    • Miscellaneous disorders: Multiple myeloma, rheumatoid arthritis, mastocytosis, thalassemia, Wilson's disease, hemochromatosis, etc.

Explanation of other options:

Denosumab (Option A): A RANKL inhibitor that prevents osteoclast maturation, effectively used in treating postmenopausal osteoporosis.

Hormone replacement therapy (Option B): Estrogen therapy reduces bone resorption and is sometimes used in postmenopausal women to prevent or treat osteoporosis.

Vertebroplasty (Option C): A minimally invasive procedure used to stabilize osteoporotic vertebral compression fractures and relieve pain.

choices.text: It is associated with elevated alkaline phosphatase levels
It commonly involves the pelvis, skull, and spine
Calcium and phosphate levels are typically decreased
Bisphosphonates are the mainstay of treatment

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with persistent bone pain in the pelvis and increasing hat size over the last year. He also complains of hearing difficulty. On examination, there is localized warmth over the tibia. X-ray pelvis shows thickened cortical bone with mixed lytic and sclerotic areas and coarse trabeculae. Laboratory investigations reveal normal calcium and phosphate levels with markedly elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP). Which of the following statements about the disease is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient has Paget's disease. Paget’s disease usually shows normal serum calcium and phosphate, with isolated elevated ALP.

  • Paget's disease (osteitis deformans) is a chronic disorder marked by abnormal bone remodeling, due to increased osteoclastic and compensatory osteoblastic activity.
  • It is commonly asymptomatic or may present with:
    • Bone pain
    • Deformities (e.g., enlarged skull, bowed tibia) (Option B ruled out)
    • Fractures
    • Neurological complications (e.g., hearing loss from cranial nerve compression)
  • Radiological Features:
    • Mixed lytic and sclerotic lesions
    • Coarse trabeculae
    • Cortical thickening
    • Picture frame vertebrae, blade of grass lesion, ivory vertebra
  • Metabolic/Laboratory Findings:
    • Increased Alkaline phosphatase (due to high osteoblastic activity) (Option A ruled out)
    • Normal serum calcium and phosphate
    • Urinary hydroxyproline may be elevated
  • Treatment:
    • Bisphosphonates (e.g., alendronate) are first-line agents (Option D ruled out)
    • They suppress osteoclasts, reduce bone turnover, and relieve symptoms

questions.text: The given x-ray finding is seen in
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given x-ray shows salt and pepper appearance of skull, which is a classical finding of Primary hyperparathyroidism

  • Primary hyperparathyroidism is due to adenoma(most common cause) or hyperplasia of the parathyroid gland that leads to increased parathormone production.
  • Most commonly it is seen in females(Female: Male-3:1) in the middle age group(40 TO 65 years).
  • For long patients may remain asymptomatic and hypercalcemia may be the only finding in blood tests.
  • Due to hypercalcemia, patients present with anorexia, nausea, depression, abdominal pain, muscle weakness and fatigue(not tetany). Increased glomerular filtration and tubular absorption of calcium causes kidney stone (nephrocalcinosis), polyurea, recurrent urinary infection and impaired renal function.
  • Osteitis fibrosa cystica(replacement of bone marrow with fibrous tissue) and hemorrhages in this fibrous tissue producing brownish, fluid-filled cystic, tumor-like masses in bones, called Brown tumors.
  • X-ray features:
    • Brown tumors: Appear as expansile cystic lytic lesions seen mostly in mandible, maxilla, ribs, clavicle and pelvis.
    • Subperiosteal resorption of the phalanges
    • Diffuse stippling may be seen in the skull called the salt and pepper appearance.
    • Resorption of lamina dura of teeth

Explanation of other options:

Eosinophilic granuloma (Option A): Typically shows punched-out lytic lesions or vertebra plana in children, not the subperiosteal bone resorption seen in primary hyperparathyroidism.

Paget's syndrome (Option B): Characterized by mixed lytic-sclerotic lesions, cortical thickening, and coarse trabeculae, especially in the skull, pelvis, and spine.

Multiple myeloma (Option D): Shows multiple punched-out lytic lesions (particularly in skull and spine), but lacks the classic subperiosteal resorption of phalanges seen in primary hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions produce the x-ray finding given in the image below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is a typical x-ray of the Rugger jersey spine. Rugger jersey spine describes the prominent endplate densities at multiple contiguous vertebral levels to produce an alternating sclerotic-lucent-sclerotic appearance.

  • This mimics the horizontal stripes of a rugby jersey.
  • Rugger jersey spine is classically seen in renal osteodystrophy. Renal osteodystrophy is the bone damage that occurs in chronic renal failure.
  • Pathology - In renal osteodystrophy, there will be secondary hyperparathyroidism because of calcium loss through the kidneys. The excess PTH will cause bone resorption throughout the body. In response to this, osteoblasts form an increased amount of osteoid that does not contain hydroxyapatite but does appear opaque on radiographs.
  • The sclerotic bands on the superior and inferior endplates of the vertebral bodies represent accumulations of excess osteoid and appear opaque because of their increased volume when compared to normal bone.

Explanation of other options:

Bisphosphonate therapy (Option B): Bisphosphonates are used to treat osteoporosis and Paget's disease; they do not cause the rugger jersey spine or other changes typical of renal osteodystrophy.

Hypercalcemia (Option C): Hypercalcemia may result from primary hyperparathyroidism or malignancy, but it does not produce characteristic radiological findings like sclerotic bands at vertebral endplates.

Primary hyperparathyroidism (Option D): Causes subperiosteal bone resorption, salt and pepper skull, and osteitis fibrosa cystica, not the rugger jersey spine classically seen in renal osteodystrophy.

choices.text: Causes widening of the zone of provisional calcification

questions.text: A 7-year-old male presents to the orthopedic clinic with leg pain that has been present for the past 6 months. On a physical exam, the patient appears malnourished. There is tenderness to palpation of the distal femur. Additionally, the gums have a bluish-purple hue with areas of hemorrhages. A radiograph of the patient's knee is demonstrated in figure. Given the most likely diagnosis, which of the following is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation and radiograph are consistent with scurvy. Scurvy leads to widening of the zone of provisional calcification which is demonstrated on radiograph as a dense band (White line of Frankl) at the growing metaphysis.

  • Scurvy is a disease resulting from a deficiency of vitamin C(ascorbic acid), which is required for the synthesis of collagen in humans.
  • This leads to decreased chondroitin sulfate synthesis which causes defective collagen growth and repair in the metaphyseal region of the long bone.
  • This defect in type I collagen synthesis primarily affects osteoblastic function.
  • As a result, this decreased osteoblastic activity leads to defective primary and secondary spongiosa of the growing long bone.
  • Histologically, the primary trabeculae of the bone is replaced with granulation tissue causing thin cortices.
  • Additionally, impaired collagen synthesis in scurvy leads to fragile capillaries, resulting in abnormal bleeding, ecchymosis and joint effusions.
  • The treatment for scurvy is prompt administration of vitamin C.

Explanation of other options:

Result of decreased osteoclast function (Option A): Decreased osteoclast function is a feature of osteopetrosis, not scurvy. Scurvy is due to vitamin C deficiency, affecting collagen synthesis and vascular integrity.

Result of Vitamin D deficiency (Option B): Vitamin D deficiency leads to rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults, not the hemorrhagic gum changes and subperiosteal bleeding typical of scurvy.

Mineralisation of bone is affected (Option C): Impaired bone mineralization is characteristic of rickets/osteomalacia; in scurvy, the issue lies with defective collagen formation, not mineralization.

Reference:

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/35380727/

questions.text: A 65-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with chronic low back pain and reduced height. She has a history of a fragility fracture of the wrist after a minor fall. Her DEXA scan shows a T-score of -3.0, consistent with osteoporosis. All of the following conditions are associated with similar changes in bone mass as seen in this patient except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Osteopetrosis is characterized by increased bone mass, unlike the reduced bone mass seen in osteoporosis, hyperparathyroidism, and osteomalacia.

Osteopetrosis:

  • Osteopetrosis is a genetic disorder of defective osteoclast function, leading to abnormally dense but brittle bones.
  • Despite increased bone mass, the bones are structurally weak and prone to fracture.
  • It is characterized by sclerosis and thickening of the bones which appear with increased radiographic density.
  • In osteopetrosis, there is failed bone resorption due to a defect in osteoclast production and/or function.
  • As a result of this bone mass is increased in this condition.
  • This does not translate into increased strength but causes increased brittleness and susceptibility to pathological fractures. This condition is also called marble bones disease or Albers-Schonberg Disease.

Explanation of other options:

Osteoporosis(Option A):

  • It is characterized by an abnormally low bone mass, normal mineral to matrix ratio and defects in bone structure, a combination which renders the bone unusually fragile and at greater than normal risk of fracture in a person of that age, sex and race.
  • In X-rays characteristic signs of osteoporosis are loss of trabecular definition, thinning of the cortices and insufficiency fractures.
  • Compression fractures of the vertebral bodies, wedging at multiple levels or biconcave distortion of the vertebral end-plates due to bulging of intact intervertebral discs are typical of severe postmenopausal osteoporosis.

Osteomalacia(Option D):

  • It is a manifestation of Vitamin D deficiency in adults.
  • There is inadequate mineralisation of bone.
  • It is characterized by a decreased ratio of bone mineral to matrix. Thus, there is a decrease in bone mineral mass.

Hyperparathyroidism(Option C):

  • It is characterized by a general loss of bone substance.
  • In severe cases, osteoclastic hyperactivity produces subperiosteal erosions, endosteal cavitation and replacement of the marrow spaces by vascular granulations and fibrous tissue(osteitis fibrosa cystica).
  • Haemorrhage and giant-cell reaction within the fibrous stroma may give rise to brownish, tumour-like masses, whose liquefaction leads to fluid-filled cysts.

questions.text: The most common deformity in Rickets is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common deformity in rickets is genu varum followed by genu valgum.

Clinical features of rickets:

  • Craniotabes(earliest sign)
  • Frontal bossing
  • Rachitic rosary
  • Harrison's sulcus
  • Pectus carinatum(pigeon chest)
  • Broadening of the ends of long bones, most prominently around wrists and knees. It is seen around 6-9 months of age.
  • Delayed teeth eruption is noticed in infants.
  • Muscular hypotonia: The child's abdomen becomes protuberant(pot belly) because of marked muscular hypotonia. Visceroptosis and lumbar lordosis can occur.
  • Deformities: Deformities of the long bones develop, once the child starts walking. The most common deformity is bilateral genu varum, also called bow legs.

X-ray Features include:

  • Epiphyseal plates widening(earliest radiological sign)
  • Fraying, splaying & cupping of metaphysis.

questions.text: Identify the given x-ray and find the correctly matched option
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given x-ray shows typical X-Ray findings in Scurvy. And white line of Frankel is correctly matched.

X-ray findings in Scurvy:

  • Diaphysis
    • Osteopenia - earliest sign
    • Ground glass appearance
    • Pencil thin cortex
    • Subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Metaphysis
    • Frankel's white line - widened zone of provisional calcification between epiphysis and metaphysis
    • Trummerfeld zone/Scorbutic zone/Scurvy line - transverse radiolucent band in the metaphysis adjacent to the Frankel line
    • Pelkan spur - metaphyseal spurs
  • Epiphysis
    • Wimberger sign - ring of increased density surrounding epiphysis

Reference:

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/35380727/

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents with diffuse bone pain, difficulty walking, and proximal muscle weakness. She follows a strict indoor lifestyle and has a history of poor nutrition. Biochemical investigations show low phosphate, elevated alkaline phosphatase, and a low-normal calcium level. A bone biopsy reveals an increased osteoid matrix that is poorly mineralized. Which of the following statements about osteomalacia are NOT true?
(A) It is caused by vitamin D deficiency
(B) It presents with proximal myopathy
(C) It shows raised serum calcium
(D) Serum calcium is always normal
(E) Bone biopsy shows increased demineralized matrix
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Osteomalacia may have normal or low serum calcium, but never elevated; calcium is not always normal, especially in more severe cases.

Raised serum calcium: Serum calcium is never elevated in osteomalacia. It is often low or low-normal due to impaired intestinal absorption.

Serum calcium is always normal

Although calcium can be normal, it is not always; low calcium is commonly seen in advanced or symptomatic cases.

  • Osteomalacia is a metabolic bone disorder seen in adults due to defective mineralization of bone matrix, commonly from vitamin D deficiency.
  • Unlike osteoporosis, where bone quantity is lost, osteomalacia is a qualitative defect, with normal bone volume but poor mineral content.
  • Key features include:
    • Bone pain, proximal muscle weakness, and gait abnormalities
    • Low or normal serum calcium
    • Low phosphate
    • Elevated alkaline phosphatase
    • Secondary hyperparathyroidism in response to hypocalcemia
    • Bone biopsy shows increased unmineralized osteoid (decalcified matrix)
  • Vitamin D deficiency is the primary cause of osteomalacia, leading to defective mineralization.
  • Proximal myopathy is a classic clinical manifestation, particularly affecting the hip and shoulder girdle.
  • Bone biopsy showing an increased demineralized matrix is the hallmark histological finding in osteomalacia.

questions.text: Which of the following does not cause secondary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Parathyroid adenoma causes primary, not secondary hyperparathyroidism.

  • Hyperparathyroidism can be primary or secondary
  • Primary hyperparathyroidism is always pathological and is seen in parathyroid tumors, which secrete large amounts of PTH without any control. So, parathyroid adenoma is a cause of primary hyperparathyroidism.
  • Secondary hyperparathyroidism is, however, usually physiological and occurs as a response to reduced calcium levels in the blood.
  • So any condition that lowers the serum calcium can trigger secondary hyperparathyroidism. E.g.
    • Vitamin D deficiency
      • Rickets
      • Osteomalacia
    • Calcium deficiency, especially in preterm infants
    • Chronic Renal failure leading to renal calcium loss

Explanation of other options:

Hyperparathyroidism in post renal transplantation patient (Option A): Persistent secondary hyperparathyroidism is common after transplantation due to long-standing renal osteodystrophy.

Osteomalacia (Option B): Vitamin D deficiency in osteomalacia leads to hypocalcemia, stimulating compensatory PTH secretion-a classic cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism.

Chronic renal failure (Option D): Reduced phosphate excretion and decreased calcitriol production in CKD cause hypocalcemia, triggering secondary hyperparathyroidism.

choices.text: Increases 1 alpha hydroxylation of vitamin D
Directly increases calcium reabsorption in intestine

questions.text: Which of the following is not an action of parathyroid hormone?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Parathyroid hormone (PTH) actually decreases phosphate reabsorption in the kidney, promoting phosphaturia.

The actions of PTH hormone are:

  • Acts on the renal tubules to increase calcium reabsorption.
  • Whenever calcium is reabsorbed, phosphate is excreted in its place, thereby reducing phosphate levels in the blood.
  • It increases 1 alpha hydroxylation of vitamin D in the kidney, which results in the formation of 1,25-OH vitamin D (also called calcitriol), which is the active form of vitamin D.
  • Increases demineralization of bone, leading to release of mineral calcium into the blood

Explanation of other options:

Increase calcium reabsorption in kidney (Option A): PTH enhances calcium reabsorption in the distal renal tubules, reducing urinary calcium loss.

Increases 1 alpha hydroxylation of vitamin D (Option C): PTH stimulates 1α-hydroxylase in the kidney, increasing production of active 1,25(OH)2 vitamin D (calcitriol).

Directly increases calcium reabsorption in intestine (Option D): Though PTH does not act directly on the intestine, it indirectly enhances intestinal calcium absorption by increasing calcitriol synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of vitamin D deficiency in children?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Double malleoli sign is a feature seen in rickets. This occurs due to the widening of the metaphysis.

  • Looser zones, also called Milkman lines, are seen in osteomalacia. (Option A and B ruled out)
  • Rickets can produce rosary, which are thickening of the costochondral junctions, but they will be painless.
  • Painful and angular rosary is seen in scurvy. (Option C ruled out)

choices.text: After the child crosses 18 yrs of age

questions.text: A 16-year-old child presented with rickets and deformities. Doctors are planning the surgical correction of these deformities. When can surgery be done?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Surgical correction in rickets is performed only after metabolic healing is complete, which is indicated by normalization of serum alkaline phosphatase.

  • In nutritional rickets, bone deformities (especially in the lower limbs) are common due to defective mineralization of growth plates.
  • Medical therapy with vitamin D and calcium is the first step.
  • Surgery is considered for persistent or severe deformities after the metabolic disorder is corrected.
  • The best indicator of healing is the normalization of serum ALP, which reflects restored osteoblastic activity and proper mineralization.
  • Serum calcium, phosphate, and PTH may normalize earlier or fluctuate, but ALP remains elevated during active disease and drops only after bone healing begins.
  • Delaying surgery until metabolic correction prevents recurrence of deformity and poor surgical outcomes.

Explanation of other options:

After serum calcium becomes normal (Option A): Serum calcium can normalize early, even before proper bone healing occurs. It is not a reliable marker for timing surgery.

After serum PTH becomes normal (Option C): While PTH elevation reflects metabolic imbalance, it may normalize before full skeletal recovery. ALP is a better indicator of bone turnover.

After the child crosses 18 yrs of age (Option D): Surgery is not age-dependent; it is based on metabolic control. Waiting unnecessarily may worsen deformities.

questions.text: Rickets is associated with
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In rickets, defective mineralization of osteoid leads to a decrease in the mineral apposition rate, reflecting poor calcium-phosphate deposition in growing bones.

  • Rickets is a disorder of the growing skeleton, primarily due to vitamin D deficiency, resulting in defective mineralization of the osteoid matrix at the growth plate.
  • Two important terminologies in association with rickets are osteoid maturation time and mineral apposition rate.
  • Osteoid maturation time - rate at which osteoid matures into osteon.
  • Mineral apposition rate - rate at which minerals are deposited on the osteon so that it matures into an osteoid.
  • Maturation is the process by which osteoid (which is the organic part of bone) is transformed into osteon (which is the basic structural unit of bone).
  • Osteoid maturation takes place by deposition of minerals on it. In rickets, the minerals are deficient, hence the process of maturation is slowed down.
  • This means that the mineral apposition rate decreases and the osteoid maturation time increases.
  • The mineral apposition rate is a histomorphometric index of how quickly a mineral is being laid down in a newly formed osteoid. In rickets, due to defective vitamin D metabolism and hypophosphatemia, this process is markedly slowed.

Explanation of other options:

Decreased osteoid volume (Option A): Osteoid volume is actually increased due to accumulation of unmineralized bone matrix.

Increased mineral apposition rate (Option B): The rate is decreased, not increased, due to delayed mineral deposition.

Decreased osteoid maturation time (Option C): Osteoid maturation time is prolonged, meaning it takes longer for Osteoid to become mineralized.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought by his parents with complaints of bowed legs, delayed milestones, and difficulty walking. On examination, the child has widened wrists, a frontal bossing, and a rachitic rosary. X-ray of the wrist shows cupping and fraying of the metaphyses. Blood investigations reveal low calcium, high alkaline phosphatase, and elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH). Which of the following is NOT typically seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Serum phosphate is decreased in nutritional rickets due to secondary hyperparathyroidism and impaired absorption, so elevated phosphate is not seen.

  • Rickets, especially nutritional rickets due to vitamin D deficiency, result in defective mineralization of osteoid and poor calcium-phosphate homeostasis.
  • The biochemical changes in rickets are:
    • Calcium - ↓ / N (Option A ruled out)
    • PTH - ↑ (Option D ruled out)
    • Serum PO4 - ↓
    • Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP) - ↑ (Option C ruled out)
    • Serum Vit D - ↓
  • Elevated phosphate is not seen unless there are renal rickets (hypophosphatemic types), which are different etiologies.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child diagnosed with nutritional rickets was started on high-dose vitamin D and calcium supplementation. On follow-up after 4 weeks, the child shows clinical improvement in terms of activity level and decreased pain. A repeat X-ray of the wrist is taken to assess response to treatment. Which of the following radiological findings is most indicative of healing in this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The white line of healing in the metaphysis indicates new mineralization and is a classic radiological sign of rickets recovery.

  • Rickets is caused by defective mineralization of the growth plate. With proper treatment (vitamin D and calcium), radiological healing typically precedes full correction of clinical deformities.
  • Key radiological sign of healing:
    • A dense white line appears at the metaphysis indicating restoration of mineralization, called the "zone of provisional calcification".
    • Other early signs of rickets (before healing):
      • Cupping, fraying, and splaying of the metaphysis
      • Pelkan spurs (bony projections at metaphyseal edges)
      • These signs begin to resolve gradually after metabolic correction, but their presence indicates active disease, not healing.

questions.text: Identify the splint used in rickets.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows a mermaid splint.

  • The Mermaid splint is specially designed to correct genu valgum or varum deformities in children with rickets, by holding both legs together in alignment.
  • In children with rickets, lower limb deformities like genu valgum (knock knees) or genu varum (bow legs) are common due to defective mineralization at the growth plate.
  • This is used in the correction of bow legs, seen usually in rickets.
  • The Mermaid splint is a night-time splint used after initiating medical treatment to gradually correct deformity by holding the legs together, promoting remodeling during skeletal growth. It is particularly useful for mild-to-moderate deformities.
  • These splints work only if the child is young and there is sufficient growth left for adequate remodeling of the deformed bone.
  • The splint is named "mermaid" because it binds both legs together like a mermaid's tail.

Explanation of other options:

Calipers (Option A): Used in polio or long-term limb support in neuromuscular conditions, not for correcting rickets deformities.

Below knee splint (Option B): Used for localized immobilization, not effective in correcting angular deformities like genu valgum/varum.

Dennis Brown splint (Option C): Used in congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV) (clubfoot), not in rickets-related limb deformities.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with diffuse bone pain, fatigue, and difficulty climbing stairs. She has a waddling gait and proximal muscle weakness. Her dietary history reveals low calcium intake and limited sun exposure. X-ray pelvis shows Looser's zones. Which of the following statements is NOT true about this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Serum phosphate is typically low in osteomalacia due to secondary hyperparathyroidism, not elevated.

  • Osteomalacia is a metabolic bone disease seen in adults, characterized by defective mineralization of osteoid due to vitamin D deficiency, impaired calcium/phosphate metabolism, or renal causes.
  • The biochemical changes in osteomalacia are:
    • Calcium - ↓ / N(Option B ruled out)
    • PTH - ↑ (Option C ruled out)
    • Serum PO4- ↓
    • Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP) - ↑ (Option A ruled out)
    • Serum Vit D - ↓

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the OPD with generalized body pain, fatigue, and difficulty walking. She has a waddling gait, and no history of trauma. X-ray pelvis reveals bilateral pseudofractures (Looser zones) involving the femoral neck and pubic rami. What is the appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Looser zones are characteristic of osteomalacia, and the mainstay of treatment is vitamin D supplementation to correct defective mineralization.

  • Osteomalacia is caused by defective mineralization of the osteoid matrix, most commonly due to vitamin D deficiency.
  • Looser zones (pseudofractures) are classic radiographic findings seen in weight-bearing bones like the femoral neck, pubic rami, and scapula.
  • The primary treatment involves:
    • High-dose vitamin D supplementation
    • Correction of dietary calcium deficiency
    • Addressing underlying causes like malabsorption or renal dysfunction
  • Surgical treatment is not indicated unless there are actual fractures or deformities after medical correction fails.

Explanation of other options:

Hemiarthroplasty (Option A): This is used for fracture neck of femur in elderly, not for metabolic bone disease without true fracture.

Denosumab injections (Option B): Denosumab is used for osteoporosis, not for osteomalacia, and can worsen hypocalcemia.

Open reduction and internal fixation (Option C): Looser zones are pseudofractures, and surgery is not the first-line treatment unless they progress to true fractures.

questions.text: Which of the following tumors can cause osteomalacia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hemangiopericytoma is a phosphaturic mesenchymal tumor that can cause tumor-induced osteomalacia by secreting FGF23, leading to phosphate wasting.

  • Rarely, tumors can produce osteomalacia by secreting a hormone called Phosphatonin.
  • This is called oncogenic osteomalacia.
  • Phosphatonin inhibits vitamin D activation and inhibits phosphate reabsorption.
  • Tumors causing oncogenic osteomalacia are:
    • Hemangiopericytoma (MC)
    • Non ossifying fibroma
    • Fibrous dysplasia
    • Fibrosarcoma
    • Osteoblastoma
    • Osteosarcoma

Hemangiopericytoma

  • Tumor-induced osteomalacia (TIO) is a rare paraneoplastic syndrome caused by mesenchymal tumors, most commonly hemangiopericytoma or similar lesions.
  • These tumors produce fibroblast growth factor 23 (FGF23), which:
    • Inhibits renal phosphate reabsorption
    • Suppresses 1-alpha hydroxylase, reducing active vitamin D
    • Leads to hypophosphatemia, low calcitriol, and defective mineralization
  • Patients present with:
    • Bone pain, muscle weakness, and fractures
    • Radiographic features of osteomalacia
  • Biochemical findings:
    • Low serum phosphate, high FGF23, low-normal calcium
  • Surgical removal of the tumor often reverses the condition.

Explanation of other options:

Chondrosarcoma (Option A): Malignant cartilaginous tumor; does not produce FGF23 or cause phosphate wasting.

Chondroblastoma (Option B): Benign epiphyseal tumor; may cause joint pain but not associated with systemic osteomalacia.

Osteoid osteoma (Option C): Painful benign bone tumor causing no systemic phosphate disturbance; pain is due to prostaglandins, not mineral imbalance.

choices.text: Overlap of Vitamin D and Vitamin C deficiency
Type of fracture of distal radius
Type of fracture of the thumb

questions.text: What is Barton's disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Barton's disease refers to a coexisting deficiency of vitamin D (rickets) and vitamin C (scurvy), usually seen in malnourished children.

  • Barton's disease is a historical clinical term used to describe cases where children suffer from both rickets and scurvy simultaneously, especially in severely malnourished populations.
  • Vitamin D deficiency causes rickets, leading to poor mineralization of bone and deformities.
  • Vitamin C deficiency causes scurvy, leading to bleeding gums, petechiae, subperiosteal hemorrhages, and defective collagen synthesis.
  • When these deficiencies occur together:
    • There is exacerbated skeletal deformity, pseudoparalysis, and poor wound healing.
    • It presents a diagnostic challenge, as clinical and radiological signs overlap or mask each other.
  • Treatment involves correcting both deficiencies with appropriate supplementation and nutritional support.

Explanation of other options:

Type of fracture of distal radius (Option B): This refers to Barton's fracture, not Barton's disease. Barton's fracture is an intra-articular distal radius fracture.

Type of renal tubular acidosis (Option C): No type of RTA is named Barton's disease.

Type of fracture of the thumb (Option D): Fractures like Bennett's or Rolando's are named for thumb base injuries, not Barton's.
